div.ab:
The Philosophers call their Stone vegetable, because it vegetates, growes,-
is increasdincreased and multipldmultiplied as a plant: which indeed to the ignorant seems
strange and contrary to truth; it being manifest that stones doe neither
vegetate, nor grow after this manner, nor any thing at all relate to-
liquable metalls: but they are deceived in their judgment: for that which
is unknowne to them they suppose is not in rerum natura, measuring
the immensity of the universe by their capacity: For who could ever
have beleived that a stone should grow under water, or a plant there ge
nerated become a stone, if experience together with the credible testimo
nyestestimonies of writes had not confirmdconfirmed it? where is that petrefyingpetrifying, where-
that tinging virtue, which hardenethhardens and tingethtinges Corall, whether in the
water, or in the aire, or in the earth? wee may reasonably beleive it
to be, as they affirme, a soft and flexible plant, whilst it is under wa
ter, yet of a very terrestriallterrestrial nature, which, when it is cut of and exposed
to the cold winds, becomes hard, and acquires a stony frangibility, the
watry parts abounding being dryeddried up by the cold and dry aire (for these
North winds blowing doe introduce siccity) and the terrestriall body-
remaining congealed with cold and siccity bybeing the qualityes of the earth:
for constriction appertainesappertains to the earth alone, not to the water, nor aire,
as to the proper and genuine virtues of either. Besides the sea in other
places yeilds three medicinall stones deduced partly from the vegetable
kind, partly from the animall, or rather partly from the secrets of na
ture; as Pearls, Ambar, and Ambar=griseAmbar=grise: the production of Pearls,-
and the way of taking them have been knowne to us, but not of the
rest: Ambar is found and gathered on the Sea coasts of Sudavia, on the
shoars, after a most vehement South or westerly wind, which without
doubt boyles out of the veins of the earth into the Sea, or is washdwashed-
out by the water, and driven by the waves to the shoars: For wee-
have seen some veins of iron and Silver swimming with the Ambar,
which could not be done but in the earth. But as to the flyes, gnatts,-
Spiders, ButterflyesButterflies, froggsfrogs, Serpents which are seen in some peicespieces (as
wee have had 120 beads turned out of Ambar, which did every one
containe some flyes, gnatts, Spiders, butterflyesbutterflies, and one particle nine,
not without a singular miracle of nature) that happens by the influ
ence and imagination of the heaven; as wee have elswhere demon
strated. That Ambar=griseAmber=grise is found after the same manner on the
Shoars of the east and west IndyesIndies, cannot be denyddenied, and though-
some declare it to be the juice or gumme of trees, as the Ambar-
aforesayd, yet they that conceive it to proceed out of veins of the-
earth doe judge more probably: For fruitfullfruitful trees of Ambar have
been in noe place seen, which notwithstanding, if there be, doe-
most certainly grow out of the water in the open aire: Wee-

therefore ascribe both sorts of Ambar to subterranean veins or stones, as
Pearls to Zoophytes (that is, a midle nature between animall and plant)-
and Corall to vegetables. The Philosophers stone is indeed like to these stones
and especially to Corall: for as Corall growes in water, and drawes nutriment
from the earth; soe allso the Philosophicall stone growes in Mercuriall-
water, and from it receives whatsoever is earthy, for the augmentation of it
selfe, the superfluous moisture expiring. A red colour is allso fixed in Corall
by coagulation, which modern authors call the tincture of Coralls, noe other
wise than as in the PhysicallPhysical stone, which becomes red in the last coagu
lation of it, and appears like the reddest Corall, which is the tincture:-
but as Corall becomes hard by cold and siccity, soe that by heat and sicci
ty, which being augmented it likewise dissolves, contrary to the nature of
other stones, which doe indeed dissolve, but turne into glasse, which thing
is noewisenowise agreable to this: And as Corall is præpared into severall medi
cines of great virtue, soe allso hath the Philosophicall Corall transferrdtransferred-
the virtues of all herbs into itselfe, soe that is alone is able to performe
as much as all the medicines of all vegetables: For the cælestiall Sunne,
which infusethinfuses medicinall virtue and efficacy into vegetables, contributes
to this its Sonne and terrestriall deputy more, than to all others: This is-
the Philosophicall vegetable, animall, and minerall Corall, which lyes
occult in the vast ocean, and is not knowne, except it be exposed to the
eyes and put into the hands of the ignorant: But it must be cut of in
the water with very great caution, lest it loose its juice and blood, and
nothing remayne but a terrestriall chaos without its true forme: For
herein consists all the difficulty of taking corall, besides which there is-
scarce any: The superfluous moisture. I meane, which kills the stone,
unlesse it be separated, which suffers not the corallinecoraline rednesse to-
appear, which admitts not coagulation, whilst it is therein. . . . .
